steps.title: Read the instructions on your softgel package to find your dosage.
steps.content: Read the instructions on your softgel package to find your dosage. Your dosage will be based on age and symptoms, and your package should detail this thoroughly. Every softgel will give different instructions based on the medication type. [1] X Research source A typical dosage could be to take 2 softgels with water every 4 hours for adults and children 12 years or over. Reviewing instructions is especially important if taking daytime or nighttime softgel products. You wouldn’t want to take a sleep aid right before you start your work day!

steps.title: Ask your doctor or pharmacist to clarify your dosage.
steps.content: Ask your doctor or pharmacist to clarify your dosage. Your prescription or over-the counter-package should list your dosage in the instructions. If it doesn’t or if you need clarification, you can ask either your doctor or pharmacist. They can clarify how much and how frequently you should take your softgels.

steps.title: Do not ingest more or less than directed.
steps.content: Do not ingest more or less than directed. You cannot break up the dosage of softgels, for their contents are liquid, so never take more or less than listed. Taking more than directed can have many different health effects including overdose, depending on the medication. Taking less than directed prevents the medication from working. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Take your softgels with or without food, based on your instructions.
steps.content: Take your softgels with or without food, based on your instructions. Most softgels are recommended to be taken with food, though it can get murky. If your instructions say to take with food, swallow your softgels with your meal or right after. If they do not, then you can take your softgels with water. [3] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Take out the correct number of pills from your softgel container.
steps.content: Take out the correct number of pills from your softgel container. Twist off or pop open the lid, and retrieve your softgels, usually about 1 or 2 at a time.

steps.title: Place your softgels in your mouth, on top of your tongue.
steps.content: Place your softgels in your mouth, on top of your tongue. Softgels are very easy to swallow and dissolve, though they come in a variety of sizes. You can take one at a time or your whole dose at once, depending on what’s comfortable for you. [4] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Sip some water as you have the softgel in your mouth.
steps.content: Sip some water as you have the softgel in your mouth. You can also sip some water before you take your pill, in case your throat is dry. [5] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Swallow both the pill and the water at the same time.
steps.content: Swallow both the pill and the water at the same time. The water will help the pill slide down your throat with ease. [6] X Research source Most softgel instructions say to drink water with your softgels to help with digestion. Unless your softgel instructions state otherwise, you can also take them with juice.

steps.title: Swallow your softgels whole.
steps.content: Swallow your softgels whole. Instead of crushing, chewing, or dissolving your softgels, swallow them with their coating intact, unless your doctor or pharmacist tells you to take them differently. Softgels contain liquid, and their outer coating is designed to dissolve in your stomach or small intestine. [7] X Research source If you crush, chew, or dissolve a softgel that's meant to be time-released, it won't be absorbed into your system properly.
